data.text: Definitely one of the cheap pocket rocket copies like others have mentioned. With a small canister it's just the most efficient with the least amount of fuss.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: Now this could be untrue, but I have heard through backpacking forums that the cheaper stoves like brs are less efficient with fuel consumption compared to the well known companies such as msr and Soto
data.author: Tim Farrell

data.text: Not in any meaningful way. I have owned both. Maybe 10% difference in my experience.
data.author: Kelly Peters

data.text: Use an alcohol stove, minimal and functional
data.author: Philip Yates

data.text: but there are many drawbacks to alcohol stoves. Alcohol stoves don’t work well in cold or windy conditions. They also use more fuel and are slower to boil. Don’t get me wrong, I love leaving the gas station with a can of beer, soup and Heet (yellow bottle). And knowing I’ve gone full Hobo. But there are better ways.
data.author: James Folsom

data.text: If you have used one you will find they work extremely well. The difference in boiling a litre of water is 2 minutes. A wind barrier (foil) solves the wind and I don't bikepack in -0 degrees. I have camped in close to 0 degrees and it is fine. Simplicity is key.
data.author: Philip Yates

data.text: In cold weather, I put my alcohol stove in my bed with me (making sure the rubber seal is intact - don't want a leak) so it's easy to light in the morning
data.author: James Fenn

data.author: Jorn Beerendonk

data.text: FyreLite Start are great if all you’re looking to do is boil some water for a brew or to rehydrate some food.
data.author: Stephen Fry

data.text: Twig stoves are cool, no need to pack fuel, but they get soot on your pot. My old Svea 123 gas stove is heavier, but works no matter how cold it gets. I have the Trangia alcohol stove, and a titanium version, but I don't seem to use them much because my canister stove is more convenient. But you can find alcohol fuel anywhere. I've never got along with solid fuel stoves. So ya, mostly canister stoves for me, except in winter where its the Svea gas stove.
data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: I use both a MSR pocket Rocket 2, a Trangia and when suitable over fire on a Wolf and Grizzly fire pit. My go to stove is the Trangia 👍🏕🍳
data.author: Jamie Bellham

data.text: Been using an eBay pocket rocket clone for about 10 years. They are really common. I think I paid $7 for it and it works well.
data.author: Tony Dangerfield

data.text: Secondhand jetboil, mounted to the bottle bosses with a voilé strap, then mount one of those tri-style bottle mounts behind the seat that stop your saddlebag from swaying
data.author: Barney Davies

data.text: Cool pic!
data.author: Rick Whitter

data.text: If it hasn’t already been said, take where you are riding into consideration when you purchase your stove. For example, a nice alcohol or wood stove won’t do you any good in an area where they are prohibited because of a fire ban.
data.author: Steve Malbrough

data.text: some places with. Allow you to use an alcohol stove or a canister stove during a fire ban since they are considered a contained fire. (Not all but some) we were in Wyoming during a ban and the park rangers said we were fine to use them.
data.author: Shane Coffey

data.text: I have the Primus Essential Trail Stove and the GSI Minimalist cookset. It does everything I need.
data.author: Drew Van Patter

data.text: BRS 3000T. $16 and one of the lightest stoves on the market. Super popular in the ultralight backpacking scene.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: Zelph's starlyte for $16 (with shipping)! It's by far the best alcohol stove I ever tried...
data.author: Fede Cabrera

data.text: Solo stick stove with alcohol burner option? Small enough to pack into an 1100ml Ti pot..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Army surplus trangia off eBay, or a home made wood-gas stove.
data.author: Adrian Hodges

data.text: I have and really like my old MSR Pocket Rocket, but I bought a TINY little cheap ti stove on amazon for like $20AUD, and use it now. It's not quite as refined, but it's really small and really light and packs away a bit easier than the older version of the PR that I have that doesn't fold down quite as well.
data.author: Erik Jansen

data.text: there is no single best because the specific conditions will vary far too much from expedition to expedition. give us more info on how long, where, what you're cooking, and under what conditions to give useful recommendations.
data.author: Hans Breaux

data.text: No longer than one week out. Used mostly to boil water for coffee and freeze dried foods. Fairly protected camping, no real roughing it.
data.author: Rick Whitter

data.text: cool, then you might want to look into an alcohol stove to get the lightest weight. it would be pretty easy to field resupply as you can use fuel line conditioner as stove fuel and it's found at almost every gas station.
